list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Let $f(x)=0.2ex+2−4$, for $−3≤x≤2$.


On the following grid, sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$. [3]



![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/4d1c7bf9-8d2a-4f7a-945e-f582b73039b2/219ede634589aee775d4d590dd79b30ff5c63914.svg)




Find the coordinates of:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept. [2]





The graph of $f$ is reflected in the $x$-axis, then translated 1 unit in the direction of the positive $x$-axis and 2 units in the direction of the positive $y$-axis to obtain the graph of a function $g$.

Find $g(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph of $y=f(x)$ for $−3≤x≤2$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7400009-b3d5-4424-8dfe-4781fa255590/images/0c8cb343-6319-4c4b-bd01-6881dfb5c2ff/a0ce7feb5a9182c2d088b3711cfba75a324b8033.svg)






Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$0.2ex+2−4x​=0≈0.996[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$(0.996,0)​$


Evaluating $y=f(x)$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$y​=f(0)=0.2e0+2−4≈−2.52​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$(0,−2.52)​$




We have
$$$g(x)​=−f(x−1)+2=−[0.2e(x−1)+2−4]+2=−0.2ex+1+6​​$$$

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
A loaf pan is made in the shape of a cylinder. The pan has a diameter of
$24cm$ and a height of
$5cm$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2c59aaf1-7a6c-449c-8cf3-e591daef9363/images/0fbe4f18-84db-44cb-b0f8-9423cd562bc4/a347288bee589088e6dce052611dad40b73c72e7.svg)




Calculate the volume of this pan. [2]



Gloria prepares enough bread dough to exactly fill the pan. The dough
was in the shape of a sphere.


Find the radius of the sphere in cm, correct to one decimal
place. [3]



The bread was cooked in a hot oven. Once taken out of the oven, the
bread was left in the kitchen.
The temperature, $T$, of the bread, in degrees
Celsius, $°C$, can be
modelled by the function
$$$T(t)=a×(1.51)−3t​+21,t≥0,$$$
where $a$ is a constant and $t$ is the time, in minutes, since the bread
was taken out of the oven.
When the bread was taken out of the oven its temperature was
$205$ $°C$.


Find the value of $a$. [2]



Find the temperature that the bread will be $10$ minutes
after it is taken out of the oven. [2]



The bread can be eaten once its temperature drops to
$35$ $°C$.


Calculate, to the nearest minute, the time since the bread
was taken out
of the oven until it can be eaten. [3]



In the context of this model, state what the value of $21$
represents. [1]
list.markScheme:
Using the volume of a cylinder formula with $r=12$ and $h=5$, we
get
$$$Vpan​​=πr2h=π(12)2(5)=720π(1)=2261.9...≈2260 cm3​​$$$


Using the volume of a sphere formula, we have
$$$Vdough​34​πr3​=Vpan​=720π[from (1)](2)​$$$
Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $r$, we obtain
$$$r≈8.1 cm​[by using G.D.C.]$$$


Solving the equation $T(0)=205$ for $a$, we find
$$$a×(1.51)0+21a+21​=205=205​$$$
$$$a=184​$$$


Evaluating $T(t)$ for $t=10$, we get
$$$T(10)​=184×(1.51)−310​+21≈67.6°C​​$$$


Solving the equation $T(t)=35$ for $t$, we obtain
$$$184×(1.51)−3t​+21t​=35≈18.8[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
$$$t≈19 minutes​$$$


$21 is the room temperature of the kitchen in degrees celsius.​$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
Atmospheric pressure, $P$, in kPa, decreases exponentially with
increasing height above sea level, $h$. The atmospheric pressure can be
modelled by the function
$$$P(h)​=101×(2225​)−h,​$$$
where
$h$ is the height above sea level in kilometres.


Write down the exact atmospheric pressure at sea level, in kPa.
[1]



Mount Kosciuszko is the highest mountain in Australia with a height of
$2228$ $metres$ above sea level at the top.


Calculate the atmospheric pressure at the top of the Mount
Kosciuszko. [2]



Calculate the height where the atmospheric pressure is
equal to $10$ kPa. [3]
list.markScheme:
$101 kPa​$


Evaluating $P(h)$ for $h=2.228$, we get
$$$P(2.228)​=101×(2225​)−2.228≈76.0 kPa​​$$$


Solving the equation $P(h)=10$ for $h$, we obtain
$$$101×(2225​)−h​=10​$$$
$$$h=18.1km​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
A population of goldfish decreases exponentially. The size of the
population, $P$, after $t$ days is modelled by the function
$$$P(t)=8000×2−t+100,t≥0.​$$$


Write down the exact size of the initial population. [1]



Find the size of the population after $5$ days. [2]



Calculate the time it will take for the size of the population to
decrease to $120$.[2]



The population will stabilize when it reaches a size of $n$.

Write down the value of $n$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t=0$, we get
$$$P(0)​=8000×20+100=8000+100=8100​​$$$


Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t=5$, we obtain
$$$P(5)​=8000×2−5+100=350​​$$$


Solving the equation $P(t)=120$ for $t$, we find
$$$8000×2−t+100​=120​$$$
$$$t=8.64 days​[by using G.D.C.]$$$


We have
$$$t→∞lim​P(t)​=t→∞lim​[8000×2−t+100]=0+100[since 2−t→0 as t→∞]=100 fish​$$$
Hence the value of $n$ is
$100​$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
It has been suggested that the number of visits (the number of hits) to
a newly launched website can be modelled by an equation of the form
$H=aNb$, where $H$ is the number of hits in each month,
$N$ is the month number, $a$ and $b$ are constants.
To test this model, a new website was created and the number of hits in
each of the first $10$ months were recorded.
The results are shown in the following table for $N=1$ and $N=2$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b778125-a3b6-46f0-ba11-0391255a023c/images/657fe392-578d-4f19-9a02-b8cc653cd7ee/bc28e82540342d957840e8bc6479dc4995148f25.svg)






Write down the value of $a$.


Find the value of $b$, giving your answer to five significant
figures. [4]





Use this model to estimate the number of hits in the
$8$th month. Give
your answer to the nearest integer. [1]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $H=32$ and $N=1$ in the equation $H=aNb$, we
have
$$$32​=a(1)b​$$$
$$$a=32​$$$


Substituting $H=100$ and $N=2$ in the equation $H=32Nb$
and solving the resulting equation for $b$, we get
$$$100b​=32(2)b=log2​(32100​)​$$$
$$$b≈1.6439​$$$




Evaluating $H=32Y1.6439$ for $N=8$, we obtain
$$$H​=32(8)1.6439≈977​​$$$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Let $f(x)=2ln(x+2)​$, for $x>−2$. The diagram below shows
part of the graph of $f$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5ca4f0d8-2c1b-4539-b90a-140704aebde0/images/41cb6db4-c952-44a9-a5d0-dc5fd6907d15/0b26b0e195f4a087c10216491d624f903712efff.svg)




Find the coordinates of:


the $x$-intercept;


the $y$-intercept. [2]





Find the equation of the vertical asymptote to the graph of $f$.
[2]



Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the
$x$-axis and
the $y$-axis. [2]
list.markScheme:
Solving the equation $f(x)=0$ for $x$, we have
$$$2ln(x+2)​x​=0=−1[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are
$(−1,0)​$


Evaluating $f(x)=2ln(x+2)​$ for $x=0$, we have
$$$f(0)​=2ln2​≈0.347​$$$
Hence the coordinates of the
$y$-intercept are
$(0,0.347)​$




We have
$$$x→0+lim​lnxx→−2+lim​ln(x+2)x→−2+lim​f(x)​=−∞=−∞=−∞​$$$
Hence
the equation of the vertical asymptote is
$x=−2​$


The area of the region enclosed by the graph of $f$, the $x$-axis
and the $y$-axis is
$$$A​=∫−10​2ln(x+2)​dx≈0.193 units2​[by using G.D.C.]​$$$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Solve the equation $log5​x−log5​4=2+log5​3$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log5​x−log5​4log5​x−log5​4log5​4x​log5​4x​4x​​=2+log5​3=log5​52+log5​3=log5​(52⋅3)=log5​75=75​$$$
$$$x=300​$$$

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Let $f(x)=ex−2$ and $g(x)=3x+k$, for $x∈R$, where
$k$ is a constant.


Find $(g∘f)(x)$. [2]



Given that
$x→−∞lim​(g∘f)(x)=−4$,
find the value of $k$. [3]

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Solve the equation $log3​x−log3​5=1+log3​4$ for $x$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log3​x−log3​5log3​x−log3​5log3​5x​log3​5x​5x​​=1+log3​4=log3​3+log3​4=log3​(3⋅4)=log3​12=12​$$$
$$$x=60​$$$

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month
later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can
be modelled by the function
$$$P(t)=50×bt,t≥0,$$$
where $t$ is the
time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town.


Find the value of $b$. [2]



Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months.
[2]



A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough water and food
to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters.

Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster
population to reach this maximum. [2]
list.markScheme:
Solving the equation $P(1)=62$ for $b$, we get
$$$50×b1b​=62=5062​​$$$
$$$b=1.24​$$$


Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t=6$, we obtain
$$$P(6)​=50×(1.24)6≈182​​$$$


Solving the equation $P(t)=2000$ for $t$, we find
$$$50×(1.24)t​=2000​$$$
$$$t≈17.1 months​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
Write the expression $4ln2−ln8$ in the form of $lnk$, where
$k∈Z$. [3]



Hence, or otherwise, solve $4ln2−ln8=−ln(2x)$. [3]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$4ln2−ln8​=ln(24)−ln8=ln16−ln8=ln(816​)=ln2​​$$$


Replacing the left hand side of the equation with $ln2$, we get
$$$4ln2−ln8ln2−ln2ln(2−1)2x2x​=−ln(2x)=−ln(2x)=ln(2x)=ln(2x)=2−1=21​x=41​​​$$$

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Solve the equation $log3​(x2−4x+4)=1+log3​(x−2)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log3​(x2−4x+4)log3​(x2−4x+4)log3​(x2−4x+4)x2−4x+4x2−7x+10(x−2)(x−5)x−5​=1+log3​(x−2)=log3​3+log3​(x−2)=log3​(3x−6)=3x−6=0=0=0[since x−2>0]​$$$
$$$x=5​$$$

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
Find the value(s) of $x$ when
$27x+2=(91​)2x+4$.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: Solve the equation $log2​(x2−2x+1)=1+log2​(x−1)$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log2​(x2−2x+1)log2​(x2−2x+1)log2​(x2−2x+1)x2−2x+1x2−4x+3(x−1)(x−3)x−3​=1+log2​(x−1)=log2​2+log2​(x−1)=log2​(2x−2)=2x−2=0=0=0[x=1, since log2​0]​$$$
$$$x=3​$$$

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
The number of users on a new social network on January 1st $2018$ was
$320000$. One year later, on January 1st $2019$, the number of users
on this network is estimated to be $350000$. The number
of the users on this network, $N$, can be modelled by the function
$$$N(t)=320000×bt,t≥0,​$$$
where $t$ is the number of years since January 1st $2018$ and $b$ is a constant.


Find the exact value of $b$. [2]



Estimate the number of the users on this network there will be in
$2023$.[2]



Determine the year during which the number of the social network users
reaches one million. [2]
list.markScheme:
We have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4d111b1-94da-4c2d-aabc-3055a43e64b6/images/74f4d1fc-b669-413e-b511-34e3d1748696/033cf3beecde613f81a96d293306464dcb68241a.svg)


Hence, solving the equation $N(1)=350000$ for $b$,
we get
$$$320000×bb​=350000=320000350000​​$$$
$$$b=3235​ or 1.09375​$$$


We have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4d111b1-94da-4c2d-aabc-3055a43e64b6/images/fa2e3ea1-8749-42d0-9007-92005a5be7d3/74c77aa092bfa1ac875f40785f7097708883e3e2.svg)


Hence, evaluating $N(t)$ for $t=5$, we obtain
$$$N(5)​=320000×(3235​)5≈500888≈501000 users​​$$$


Solving the equation $N(t)=1000000$
for $t$, we find
$$$320000×(3235​)tt​=1000000≈12.7 years[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
If we determine the years corresponding to $t=12$ and $t=13$, we
have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4d111b1-94da-4c2d-aabc-3055a43e64b6/images/ab5f2498-70aa-47ab-adb5-d67459b0ff99/a616f6ab254b62e363c8d49827ba23ea9d06f1c6.svg)


Hence the number of network users reaches one million
$during 2030​$

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The number of French words, $N$, that are remembered by students after
the completion of a French language course decreases exponentially over
time. This data can be modelled by the function
$$$N(t)=a×b−t+450,​$$$
where $a$ and $b$ are
positive constants, and $t$ is the time in years since a student
completed the French language course.
Immediately after completion, a student remembers $4200$ French words.


Find the value of $a$. [2]



After $4$ years a student remembers only $1600$ French words.


Find the value of $b$. [3]



The number of French words a student remembers never decreases below a
certain number of words, $n$.

Write down the value of $n$. [1]
list.markScheme:
Solving the equation $N(0)=4200$ for $a>0$, we get
$$$a×b−0+450a+450​=4200=4200​$$$
$$$a=3750​$$$


Solving the equation $N(4)=1600$ for $b>0$, we obtain
$$$3750×b−4+450​=1600​$$$
$$$b≈1.34​[by using G.D.C.]$$$


If we draw the graph of $y=N(t)$, for $t≥0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae22b8f9-7634-40e8-aa58-691d50b856e0/images/ebf0ad48-65c4-4d56-9d2b-a25feec366d1/5f0266262d56defec1ffa52f191a9228b568fd3e.svg)


Hence the value of $n$ is
$450​$

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
Show that $12logx​2=log2​x12​$. [1]



Hence solve the equation $log2​x=8−12logx​2$.[4]
list.markScheme:
Using the change of base formula we can write
$$$L.H.S.​=12logx​2=12(log2​xlog2​2​)​A1​$$$
As $logn​n=1$, we can replace $log2​2$ with 1 and simplify
$$$​=12(log2​x1​)=log2​x12​​ ...as required=R.H.S.​$$$


We can replace $12logx​2$ with the R.H.S. of the identity from part (a)
$$$log2​xlog2​x​=8−12logx​2=8−log2​x12​​(M1)​$$$
We now multiply each side by $log2​x$ and then rearrange such that the R.H.S. is equal to $0$
$$$(log2​x)2(log2​x)2−8log2​x+12​=8log2​x−12=0​(M1)​$$$
This is a hidden quadratic equation.  If we replace $log2​$ with a variable, say $a$, we get
$$$a2−8a+12​=0​$$$
Let's solve this by factorising.
$$$(a−2)(a−6)​=0​$$$
Therefore the solutions are
$$$a−2a​=0=2​and​​a−6=0a=6​$$$
Recall $a=log2​x$, therefore the solutions become
$$$log2​x​=2​​​log2​x=6​A1​$$$
Converting each to exponential form, we get
$$$x​=22x=4​​​​x=26x=64​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 18
list.content: Solve $log6​(x)+log6​(x−5)=2$, for $x>5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$log6​(x)+log6​(x−5)log6​(x(x−5))log6​(x2−5x)x2−5xx2−5x−36(x+4)(x−9)x−9​=2=log6​62=log6​36=36=0=0=0[since x+4>0]​$$$
$$$x=9​$$$

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
A species of bird, thought to be extinct, was rediscovered on 14 March 1973. Through a careful protection and breeding program, the population has continued to increase since then.
The Department of conservation proposes that the population of birds $t$ years after 14 March 1973 can be modelled by the function $P(t)=10ekt$, where $0<k<1$ and $t≥0$.
On 14 March 1993 the known population of birds was 50.

Use the model to estimate the population of birds on 14 March 2023.[4]


In fact, the known population of birds on 14 March 2023 was 502. A new model is proposed in which


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff8e3fb3-2cb7-4a68-a0dc-6336d4622a74/images/27c91424-1b2d-4877-b2f4-eb19bd8a8ab9/aa987.PNG)



Find the value of $r$.[3]
list.markScheme:
14 March 1993 is 20 years after 14 March 1973, therefore $P(20)=50$. We have
$$$P(20)50e20k​=10e20k=10e20k=5​$$$
Using the numerical solver on the G.D.C. we find that $k≈0.08047$. Hence our model is $P(t)=10e0.08047t$.
14 March 2023 is 50 years after 14 March 1973, hence we calculate $P(50)$:
$$$P(50)​=10e0.08047×50P(50)≈559​​$$$


If something increases at a constant rate, the compound interest formula applies. Using the formula for compound interest with $PV=10$, $FV=502$, $k=1$ and $n=50$, we have
$$$FV502​=PV×(1+100kr​)kn=10×(1+100r​)50​$$$
Using the numerical solver on the G.D.C. we find that $r≈8.15​$

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
Find the values of $x$ when
$25x2−2x=(1251​)4x+2$.

list.title: Question 21
list.content: Solve the equation $9x+2⋅3x+1=1$.
list.markScheme:
If we substitute $y=3x$ in the equation $9x+2⋅3x+1=1$, we
have
$$$(3x)2+6⋅3x−1y2+6y−1​=0=0​$$$
Hence, using the quadratic formula, we
get
$$$y​=2(1)−6+62−4(1)(−1)​​[since y=3x>0]=2−6+210​​=−3+10​​$$$
Hence, using the properties of
logarithms, we obtain
$$$3x​=−3+10​​$$$
$$$x=log3​(−3+10​)​$$$

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
The temperature of a chocolate is given by the equation
$$$T(t)=A(2−kt)+B$$$
where $A$ and $B$ and $k$ are constants, $k>0$, $T$ is measured in degrees Celsius and $t$ is the number of minutes since the chocolate was served.
It is known that the initial temperature is $84∘$ and the temperature at time $t=k1​$ is $52∘$.

Show that $A=64$ and $B=20$. [2]


It took $40$ minutes to get a temperature of $23∘$.


Find the value of $k$.[2]



Find the number of minutes it takes to get a temperature of $21∘$.[2]
list.markScheme:
Since the initial temperature is $84∘$, we obtain
$$$T(0)84​=A(2−k(0))+B=A+B[1]​A1​$$$
Evaluating $T$ at $t=k1​$, we get
$$$T(k1​)52​=A(2−k/k)+B=2A​+B[2]​A1​$$$
To find $A$ take the difference $[2]−[1]$, we get
$$$​A=64​​$$$
Finally, using $[1]$, we get
$$$​B=20​​$$$


Solving for $k$ in the equation $T(40)=24$, we obtain
$$$64(2−k(40))+20​=23=0.11037...k=0.110​​M1A1​$$$


Solving for $t$, $T(t)=21$, we obtain
$$$64(2−0.110t)+20​=21=54.545...t=54.5minutes​​M1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Consider the function $f(x)=2ex−e−x​$, $x∈R$.

Show that $f$ is an odd function. [2]


Now, consider the function $g$ given by $g(x)=2xx4+2​$ , $x∈R,x=0$.

By considering the graph of $y=f(x)−g(x)$, solve $f(x)>g(x)$ for $x∈R$. [4]
list.markScheme:
Evaluating $f(−x)$, we get
$$$f(−x)​=2e−x−e−(−x)​=2e−x−ex​=−2ex−e−x​=−f(x)​$$$
$Therefore, f(x) is an odd function​$


If $f(x)−g(x)>0$, then $f(x)>g(x)$. Using G.D.C., we get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cf76b687-c4cf-4f02-a51c-0d0d8c929218/images/0ae01be6-8c62-4dff-b5d4-bdc1c895874f/AA930a.PNG)


We see that $f(x)−g(x)>0$ for $−4.55<x<0$ and $x>4.55$.
Therefore $f(x)>g(x)$ over the intervals
$−4.55<x<0 and x>4.55​$

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
Solve the equation $154a=81a+2$ for $a$. Express your answer in
terms of $ln3$ and $ln5$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get
$$$154a(3⋅5)4a34a⋅54a54aln54a4aln5​=81a+2=34(a+2)=34a⋅38=38=ln38=8ln3​$$$
$$$a=ln52ln3​​$$$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=logk​(8x−2x2)$, for $0<x<4$, where $k>0$.
The equation $f(x)=3$ has exactly one solution. Find the value of $k$.
list.markScheme:
If we rewrite the equation $f(x)=3$ in the form $ax2+bx+c=0$,
we have
$$$logk​(8x−2x2)8x−2x20​=3=k3=2x2−8x+k3​$$$
Hence the quadratic function
$q(x)=2x2−8x+k3$ has two equal roots.
Therefore we get
$$$[discriminant of q](−8)2−4(2)(k3)64−8k38−k3k3​=0=0[△=b2−4ac]=0=0=8​$$$
$$$k=2​$$$

list.title: Question 26
list.content:
The following table shows values of $lnx$ and $lny$.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3a04f4a1-a826-48f2-bca8-98fd950a79ca/images/3da98a42-5a0a-4c77-b19c-6a43e2e50c69/8c64f77af5ec93279ceb96452d0a87f353ec5871.svg)


The relationship between $lnx$ and $lny$ can be modelled by the
regression equation $lny=alnx+b$.


Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [3]



Use the regression equation to estimate the value of
$y$  when
$x=4.12$. [3]



The relationship between $x$ and $y$ can be modelled using the formula
$y=pxq$, where $p=0$ and $q=0$, $q=1$.

Expressing $lny$ in terms of $lnx$, find the value of
$p$ and the value of $q$. [6]
list.markScheme:
$a≈−0.564​$
and  $b≈4.74​$
[$by using G.D.C.$]


Substituting $x=4.12$ in the equation
$lny=−0.564lnx+4.74$, we get
$$$lnyy​=−0.564ln(4.12)+4.74=e−0.564ln(4.12)+4.74​$$$
$$$y≈51.5​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we have
$$$lnylnylnyyy​=−0.564lnx+4.74=lnx−0.564+lne4.74=ln([x−0.564][e4.74])=[e4.74][x−0.564]=114x−0.564​$$$
Hence we obtain
$p≈114​$
and
$q≈−0.564​$

list.title: Question 27
list.content:
A population of endangered snow leopards, $P$, can be modelled by the
equation
$$$Pt​=P0​ekt,​$$$
where $P0​$ is the initial population,
and $t$ is measured in years.


After one year, it is estimated that $P0​P1​​=0.93$.


Find the value of $k$.


Interpret the meaning of the value of $k$. [3]





Find the least number of whole years for which
$P0​Pt​​<0.50$. [5]
list.markScheme:
Substituting $t=1$ in the equation $Pt​=P0​ekt$, we have
$$$P1​P0​P1​​0.93k​=P0​ek(1)=ek=ek=ln0.93​$$$
$$$k≈−0.0726​$$$


$The rate at which the population of leopards exponentially decrease​$




We have
$$$P0​Pt​​e−0.0726t−0.0726ttt​<0.50<0.50<ln0.50>−0.0726ln0.50​>9.55​$$$
Hence the least number of whole years
for which $P0​Pt​​<0.50$ is
$t=10​$

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
The amount, in milligrams, of a medicinal drug in the body $t$ hours after it is injected is given by
$$$D(t)=240e−kt​$$$
Where $k>0$ and $t≥0$. Before the injection, it is assumed the amount of drug in the body is zero.
A patient is to be injected with the drug and, for this patient, it is known that it takes $5$ hours for the amount of drug remaining in the body to have decreased by $65%$ of the initial dose.
The patient is regularly checked and is allowed to go home when the amount of drug remaining in the body is $10%$, or less, of the initial dose.
The initial dose is given to the patient at $9:00$am.
Use this model to estimate, to the nearest hour, the earliest time the patient will be allowed to go home.
list.markScheme:
This model has a fixed value of $k$. In order to use the model we must find $k$.
First, we can find the initial amount of the drug injected into the patient, this occurs when $t=0$
$$$D(0)D(0)​=240e−k(0)=240​$$$
Five hours later, $t=5$, we are told that $100%−65%=35%$ of the initial $240 mg$ remains.
We can use this to find $k$.
$$$0.35×2400.35ln0.35​=240e−5k=e−5k=lne−5k​(M1)​$$$
Using the log law $loga​xm=mloga​x$, we get
$$$ln0.35​=−5klne​$$$
Since $lne=1$, we can simplify the equation and solve for $k$.
$$$ln0.35k​=−5k=−5ln0.35​=0.2099…​A1​$$$
We can now write out the model with out value of $k$
$$$D(t)​=240e−0.2099...t​$$$
We need to find $t$ when the drug remaining in the body is equal to $0.10×240=24 mg$.
Hence we need to solve the following equation
$$$24​=240e−0.2099…t​(M1)​$$$
We can do this graphically by sketching the function $y=D(t)$ and the horizontal line $y=24$


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/557cb4b2-cf52-4e41-839f-d59ccec63164/images/c8cc79ea-577b-410b-8eae-fb745656bc8d/AA1284.JPEG)


The $x−$coordinate of the intersection point is the solution.
Although a calculator method is preferred, an algebraic approach is also included in case you attempted it that way
$$$0.1ln0.1ttt​=e−0.2099…t=−0.2099…t=−0.2099…ln0.1​=10.96…=11to the nearest hour​A1​$$$
Converting the answer to a time we get
$$$9:00 + 11 hours = 20:00​$$$
Therefore the earliest time, to the nearest hour, the patient will be allowed to go home is
$$$20:00 or 8:00pm​​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
Solve the equation $146x=64x+3$ for $x$. Express your answer in
terms of $ln2$ and $ln7$.
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of exponents and logarithms, we get
$$$146x(2⋅7)6x26x⋅76x76xln76x6xln7​=64x+3=26(x+3)=26x⋅218=218=ln218=18ln2​$$$
$$$x=ln73ln2​​$$$

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
Write down the domain and range of the logarithmic function
$y=loga​x$
where $a>0$ and $a=1$. [2]



Given that $logx2​y=9logy​(x2)$, find all the possible
expressions
of $y$ as a function of $x$. [6]
list.markScheme:
We have
$$$domain:range:​(0,∞)​R​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$logx2​yln(x2)lny​2lnxlny​(lny)2lnylny​=9logy​(x2)=lny9ln(x2)​=lny18lnx​=(6lnx)2=±6lnx=ln(1/x6) or ln(x6)​$$$
$$$y=x61​ or x6​$$$

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
A geometric sequence, with common ratio $r$, has a first term of $81$. The sum of the first four terms of the sequence is $195$.




Find $r$.


Hence, find $Gn​$, the sum of the first $n$ terms of the geometric sequence. [3]





The first three terms of an arithmetic sequence, with a common difference of $d$, are $log96,log48$ and $log24$.

Find $d$ in the form $plogq$ where $p,q∈Z$.[2]


$An​$ is the sum of the first $n$ terms of the arithmetic sequence.


Show that $An​=log(3n×(2​)11n−n2)$.[5]



Find the maximum value of $n$ such that $∣Gn​∣>∣An​∣$.[3]
list.markScheme:
From the given information we know $u1​=81$ and $S4​=195$.
Using the formula for the sum of a geometric sequence we can form an equation and then solve for $r$.
$$$Sn​S4​195​=1−ru1​(1−rn)​=1−ru1​(1−r4)​=1−r81(1−r4)​​(M1)​$$$
Using a G.D.C. we get
$$$rr​=0.6666...=32​​​A1​$$$


Using the answer from (a) (i) and the formula for the sum of the first $n$ terms of a geometric series we can write the general term for $Gn​$ as
$$$Gn​​=1−32​81(1−(32​)n)​=31​81(1−(32​)n)​=81(1−(32​)n)×3=243(1−(32​)n)​​A1​$$$




In an arithmetic sequence, there is a common difference between terms.
$$$d​=u2​−u1​​$$$
Substituting the given values for $u1​$ and $u2​$ we get
$$$ddddd​=log48−log96=log(9648​)=log21​=log2−1=−log2​​(M1)A1​$$$


The formula for sum of an arithmetic sequence is
$$$Sn​​=2n​(2u1​+(n−1)d)​$$$
Substituting $u1​=log96$ and $d=−log2$
$$$An​​=2n​(2log96+(n−1)(−log2))=2n​(log962−(n−1)log2)​(M1)​$$$
Applying logarithm rules we get
$$$​=2n​(log962−log2(n−1))=2n​log2(n−1)962​=log(2(n−1)962​)2n​=log(2(n−1)962​)n​=log(2(n−1)​962​​)n=log((2​)n2−n96n​)​(M1)A1​$$$
Looking at the form of the answer we can attempt to rewrite the denominator using by negating its exponent
$$$​=log(96n×(2​)n−n2)​$$$
Let's rewrite $96$ as a product of prime factors
$$$​=log((25×3)n×(2​)n−n2)​M1​$$$
Then we'll rewrite $25$ as a base of $2​$
$$$​=log(((2​)10×3)n×(2​)n−n2)​$$$
Now we can distribute the power of $n$ and then use exponent laws again to simplify to the required form.
$$$​=log((2​)10n×3n×(2​)n−n2)=log(3n×(2​)10n+n−n2)=log(3n×(2​)11n−n2)​as required.​A1​$$$


Using the functions from (a) (ii) and (c) we can form an inequality which we can solve for $n$.
$$$​243(1−(32​)n)​>​log(3n×(2​)11n−n2)​​(M1)​$$$
We can sketch the $L.H.S.$ and the $R.H.S.$ on a G.D.C. to get


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e23a1ae5-5d5c-482f-938e-73e0ce7e1e6c/images/b8df9ab9-e17d-4209-a669-3c2f3e7c07be/AA1275.JPEG)


Hence when
$$$n<47.88...​A1​$$$
then $∣Gn​∣>∣An​∣$.
As $n$ represents the term value, we therefore round down to the nearest integer value.
Hence $n=47​$.
$$$​A1​$$$

list.title: Question 32
list.content:
A study records the number of chickens and ducks on a farm after $t$
years, starting on $1$ January, $1997$.
Let $c$ be the number of chickens on the farm after $t$ years. The
following table shows the number of chickens after $t$ years.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eddb9af6-2979-4663-b356-aae66d82bbe2/images/ef1a9db4-9cec-44f2-968d-e7a66d2ed51f/445a139e443a870563b0c4df38d9119c2a8c93c1.svg)


The relationship between the variables can be modelled by the regression
equation $c=at+b$, where $a$ and $b$ are constants.


Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [3]



Use the regression equation to estimate the number of chickens on
the farm when $t=6$. [2]



Let $d$ be the number of ducks on the farm after $t$ years. The number
of ducks can be modelled by the equation $d=400e−kt$, where $k$ is
a constant.


Find the number of ducks on the farm on $1$ January,
$1997$. [3]



After six years, there are $377$ ducks on the farm. Find
the value of $k$. [3]



Find the year during which the number of chickens and ducks
were the same.[4]
list.markScheme:
$a≈14.9​$  and
$b≈119​$
[$by using G.D.C.$]


Evaluating $c(t)=14.9t+119$ for $t=6$, we get
$$$c(6)​=14.9(6)+119≈208 chickens​​$$$


Evaluating $d(t)=400e−kt$ for $t=0$, we obtain
$$$d(0)​=400e−k(0)=400 ducks​​$$$


Solving the equation $d(6)=377$ for $k$, we find
$$$400e−k(6)​=377​$$$
$$$k≈0.00987​[by using G.D.C.]$$$


Solving the equation $c(t)=d(t)$ for $t$, we find
$$$14.9t+119t​=400e−0.00987t≈15.1 years[by using G.D.C.]​$$$
Hence the number of chickens and ducks were the same during
$2012​$

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
Let $f(x)=e3sin(4πx​)$, for $x>0$.
The $k$th maximum point on the graph of $f$ has $x$-coordinate $xk​$,
where $k∈Z+$.


Given that $xk+1​=xk​+d$, find $d$. [4]



Hence find the value of $n$ such that
$k=1∑n​xk​=992$. [4]
list.markScheme:
If we draw the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bd4c0fbe-80c8-4f0f-b563-49e7510420be/images/885e8a5e-4313-4a8b-a394-adbac59e4041/97f38ce996ffbe7f9b884196663bd4ac3db522d5.svg)


Hence, using the $x$-coordinates of the points A$(2,20.1)$ and
B$(10,20.1)$, we get
$$$x2​10​=x1​+d=2+d​$$$
$$$d=8​$$$


We have an arithmetic sequence with the first term $x1​=2$ and the
common difference $d=8$.
Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$Sn​=2n​(2x1​+(n−1)d)$, we
obtain
$$$k=1∑n​xk​Sn​2n​(2(2)+(n−1)(8))​=992=992[with x1​=2 & d=8]=992​$$$
$$$n=16​[by using G.D.C.]$$$

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
Consider $f(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$.


Find the largest possible domain $D$ for $f$ to be a function.
[2]



The function $f$ is defined by
$f(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$, for $x∈D$.


Sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$, showing clearly the
equations of asymptotes and the coordinates of any intercepts with
the axes. [3]



Explain why $f$ is an even function. [1]



Explain why the inverse function $f−1$ does not exist.
[1]



The function $g$ is defined by
$g(x)=21​−ln(x2−4​)$, for
$x∈(2,∞)$.

Find the inverse function $g−1$ and state its domain.
[4]
list.markScheme:
The square root function is defined on $[0,∞)$ and natural
logarithm function is defined on $(0,∞)$.
Hence $f$ is a function if
$$$x2−4​x2−4x2∣x∣x<−2​>0>0>4>2orx>2​$$$
Hence the largest possible domain for $f$ to be a function is
$$$D=(−∞,−2)∪(2,∞)​​$$$


If we sketch the graph of $y=f(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18ea91ad-1794-4924-860f-5cce1a2aaaa5/images/52aadecb-f956-431e-9b31-87bfc4bc127b/c292af76cbb30669709b70ec8dbfa255472cb0f7.svg)




$The function f is even because its graph is symmetric about the y-axis.​$
OR
$The function f is even because it satisfies f(x)=f(−x) for all x∈D.​$


$The inverse function f−1 does not exist because f is not bijective.​$


If we solve the equation $(g∘g−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=g−1(x)$, we get
$$$g(g−1(x))g(y)21​−ln(y2−4​)ln(y2−4​)y2−4​y2−4y2y​=x=x=x=21​−x=e(21​−x)=e2(21​−x)=e1−2x+4=e1−2x+4​​$$$
Hence an expression for $g−1$ is
$g−1(x)=e1−2x+4​​$
The domain of $g−1$ is
$R​$

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Show that $3loga3​x=loga​x$ where $a$, $x∈R+$.
[2]


It is given that
$log2​y+log8​4x2+log8​2x=0$.

Express $y$ in terms of $x$. Give your answer in the form
$y=bxc$ where $b$, $c$ are constants.[6]


The region $R$, is bounded by the graph of the function found in part
(b), the $x$-axis, and the lines $x=1$ and $x=k$ where $k>1$. The area
of $R$ is $23​$.

Find the value of $k$.[4]
list.markScheme:
Using the properties of logarithms, we get
$$$3loga3​x​=3loga​a3loga​x​=3​3​loga​x​=loga​x​​$$$


Using the properties of logarithms and part (a), we get
$$$log2​y+log8​4x2+log8​2xlog2​y+log8​8x3log2​y+3log8​2xlog2​y+log2​2xlog2​ylog2​y​=0=0=0=0=−log2​2x=log2​(2x)−1y=21​x−1​​$$$


First we find the area of $R$ using integration, we have
$$$Area of R23​lnk​=∫1k​21​x−1dx=[21​lnx]1k​=21​lnk=21​lnk=3k=e3​​$$$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
The function $f$ is defined by $f(x)=e2x−4ex+2$, for
$x∈R$, $x≤a$, where $a∈R$.
Part of the graph of $y=f(x)$ is shown in the following diagram.


![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4c5c56b3-ccff-4218-8eeb-ed43662a5361/images/6b8a627c-1929-4344-ac27-a9f1d77bd6ab/dc14321f698d30780f4ecaf20c082a22181a9565.svg)




Find the largest value of $a$ such that $f$ has an inverse function.
[3]



For this value of $a$, find an expression for $f−1(x)$, stating
its domain. [5]
list.markScheme:
From the diagram, we see that the $x$-coordinate of the local
minimum point on the graph of $y=f(x)$ is the largest value of $a$
such that $f$ has an inverse function.
We have
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[e2x−4ex+2]=2e2x−4ex=[2ex][ex−2]​$$$
If we solve the equation $f′(x)=0$ for $x$, we get
$$$[2ex][ex−2]ex−2exx​=0=0=2=ln2​$$$
Hence we find
$a=ln2​$


If we solve the equation $(f∘f−1)(x)=x$ for
$y=f−1(x)$, we obtain
$$$f(f−1(x))f(y)e2y−4ey+2[(ey)2−4ey]+2[(ey−2)2−4]+2(ey−2)2ey−2ey−2eyy​=x[where −2≤x<2]=x[where y≤ln2]=x=x=x[by completing the square]=x+2=±x+2​=−x+2​[since y≤ln2]=2−x+2​=ln(2−x+2​)​$$$
Hence we find
$f−1(x)=ln(2−x+2​), for x∈R,−2≤x<2​$

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
The brightness of a star can be measured in terms of its apparent magnitude as seen from Earth. The apparent magnitude $M$ of a star is given by the formula
$$$M=−2.5log(F0​F​)$$$
where $F$ is the observed flux density and $F0​$ is a reference flux density.


Solve for $F$ in terms of $M$.[2]



Suppose that $M(F1​)=1$ and $M(F6​)=6$. Find the value of $F6​F1​​$.[1]



Now, let's look at the difference in magnitude of two starts. Suppose that star $1$ has observed flux density of $F1​$ with magnitude $M1​$ while star $2$ has flux density $F2​$ with magnitude $M2​$.

Find an expression for the difference in magnitude $M2​−M1​$.[2]


The apparent magnitude of the sun is $Ms​=−26.8$ and the apparent magnitude of the full moon is $Mm​=−12.7$.

Their brightness factor is $Fm​Fs​​=10ba​$ where $a,b∈Q+$. Find $a$ and $b$.[2]
list.markScheme:
By applying logarithm and exponential properties, we have
$$$MM2.5⋅log(F)log(F)F​=−2.5[log(F)−log(F0​)]=−2.5⋅log(F)+2.5⋅log(F0​)=2.5⋅log(F0​)−M=log(F0​)−2.5M​=F0​⋅10−2.5M​​M1A1​$$$


Using the previous answer, we have
$$$F6​F1​​​=F0​​⋅10−2.56​F0​​⋅10−2.51​​=10−2.56​10−2.51​​=102.56​−2.51​=102=100​​A1​$$$


Using logarithm properties again, we obtain
$$$M2​−M1​​=−2.5log(F0​F2​​)−[−2.5log(F0​F1​​)]=−2.5[log(F0​F2​​)−log(F0​F1​​)]=−2.5[log(F0​F2​​÷F0​F1​​)]=−2.5[log(F0​F2​​÷F0​F1​​)]=−2.5log(F1​F2​​)​​M1A1​$$$


From part (c), we have
$$$−2.5log(Fm​Fs​​)log(Fm​Fs​​)Fm​Fs​​​=Ms​−Mm​=−2.5−26.8−(−12.7)​=10−2.5−14.1​a=14.1 and b=2.5​​A1A1​$$$

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
Consider the function defined by $f(x)=(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x$ for
$x∈R$, $x>p$.


Find the value of $p$. [2]



Find an expression for $f′(x)$. [3]



The graph of $y=f(x)$ has no points of
inflexion.

Determine if the graph of $y=f(x)$ is concave down or
concave up over its domain. [3]


The function $g$ is defined by $g(x)=3ln(x+31​)+x$,
for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.


Find an expression for $g′(x)$. [4]



Find the horizontal and vertical asymptotes of
$g′(x)$.[2]



Find the exact value of the minimum of $y=g(x)$.[3]



Solve $f(x)<g(x)$ for $x∈R$, $x>−3$.[5]
list.markScheme:
Due to the natural log term, $x+3>0$. Therefore
$p=−3​$


Differentiating $f$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′(x)​=dxd​[(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x]=x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1​​$$$


Differentiating $f′$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$f′′(x)​=dxd​[x+32x−6​+2ln(x+3)+1]=(x+3)2(x+3)(2)−(2x−6)​+x+32​=(x+3)22x+18​​$$$
Hence, over $x>−3$, we have $f′′(x)>0$. Therefore,
$f is concave up​$


Differentiating $g$ with respect to $x$, we obtain
$$$g′(x)​=dxd​[3ln(x+31​)+x]=3(x+3)(−(x+3)21​)+1=x+3−3​+1=x+3x​​​$$$


The denominator of $g′$ is zero when $x=−3$.
Hence,
$the line x=−3 is a vertical asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$
If we take the limit as $x$ tends to $∞$, we have
$$$x→∞lim​g′(x)​=x→∞lim​x+3x​=x→∞lim​1+x3​1​=1​$$$
Hence,
$the line y=1 is a horizontal asymptote of the graph of y=g′(x)​$


From part (d) we obtain a stationary point at $x=0$.
The second derivative of $g$ is
$$$g′′(x)​=dxd​[x+3x​]=(x+3)23​​$$$
Hence, $g′′(x)>0$ which implies that at $x=0$ the function $g$
reaches its minimum. Therefore, the minimum value of $g$ is
$$$g(0)​=3ln(31​)+0=−3ln(3)​​$$$


Using logarithm properties, we get
$$$f(x)(2x−6)ln(x+3)+x(2x−6)ln(x+3)(2x−3)ln(x+3)​<g(x)<3ln(x+31​)+x<−3ln(x+3)<0​$$$
Thus, we have two options
$$$[2x−3<0&ln(x+3)>0][x<1.5&ln(x+3)>0]x<1.5−2<​ or [2x−3>0&ln(x+3)<0] or [x>1.5&ln(x+3)<0]&1<x+3[since ln(x+3)>0 for x>1.5]x<1.5​$$$
Therefore,
$f(x)<g(x)$ over $−2<x<1.5​$
